pages.text: There are three dedicated fluid storage tanks, imaginatively titled the $(item)Small Tank/$, the $(item)Medium Tank/$, and the $(item)Large Tank/$. While $(l:machines/liquid_hopper)Liquid Hoppers/$ are also suitable for general fluid storage, these tanks provide denser fluid storage and some useful stacking functionality, and don't automatically transfer fluids (although they can push fluids with a $(l:base_concepts/upgrades#dispenser)Dispenser Upgrade/$).

pages.title: Stacking
pages.text: All three types of tank can be $(thing)stacked/$ vertically, and formed into a sort-of-multiblock. To do this, right-click the tank with a $(l:tools/pneumatic_wrench)Wrench/$; wrenching the top half will attempt to join the tank to the tank above, and vice versa for the tank below. Once tanks are stacked, any fluid in $(ttcolor)$(t:If the fluid has a density of < 0, it will move up rather than down)higher tanks/$ will automatically flow down to lower tanks, assuming there is space.

There are some restrictions to this:$(li)To combine two tanks, either both must contain the same fluid (or no fluid), or one of the tanks must be empty$(li)Fluid will $(italic)not/$ move upwards; therefore fluid should be pumped into the top tank of a stack, and pumped out of the bottom tank for best results$(li)The tank GUI will only show the fluid quantity of the tank that was right-clicked.
